course.subject: CHEM
course.name: General Chemistry II
course.description: This course is designed for students who have taken General Chemistry I and want to continue to expand their chemistry knowledge. It will cover topics related to stoichiometry and chemical reactions, properties of aqueous solutions, acids and bases, thermodynamics and equilibrium, electrochemistry, general aspects in chemistry of the main-group elements, and introduction to transition metal elements and coordination compounds.
course.prerequisites: Grade C+ or above in CHEM 1008 OR Level 4 or above in HKDSE 1x Chemistry OR CHEM 1010 OR CHEM 1020

reviews.author: Sonic12
reviews.title: Review of CHEM1030
reviews.comment_content:
1. Chemical Thermodynamics

2. Chemical Equilibrium

3. Solubility and Solution Properties

4. Acids and Bases

5. Chemical Kinetics

6. The Main Group Elements (skipped)

7. Transition Metals

8. Redox and Electrochemistry (skipped)

The professor didn't have enough time to cover ch 6 and 8
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Jason is a good man and always keen to answer the students' questions. He sometimes shows some chemical experiments during the lectures and tries to make students understand the chemical concepts.

However, don't know whether this is the first time for him lecturing the general chemistry II course or as his specialty is organic chemistry, not physical/inorganic chemistry which is highly related to chem 1030 contents, he made some critical mistakes in solving problems during the lecture or in tutorial videos. Several students had to point out the mistakes and correct them.

As he is an organic chemist, some course contents are way too focused on organic chemistry, such as a curved arrow mechanism or figuring out the number of stereoisomers.

And in chapter 7, I don't think it's necessary to cover symmetry labels and MO diagram of the octahedral case that appear in inorganic chemistry as not only chemistry students but also students from other departments attend this lecture. Rather, he should have covered crystal fields of other molecular geometries additional to octahedral.

Some contents in this course seem too much for the general chemistry level.

Maybe too in-depth explanations of chemical concepts and not having additional tutorial classes led to the lack of time to cover redox and electrochemistry which are somewhat important concepts to learn at the general chemistry level.
reviews.comment_grading:
three graded quizzes (20%)
- Most of the questions can be prepared by reviewing questions from lecture notes and practice problem sets
- Some questions may be a bit harder than you expected.

mid-term (30%)
- As the submission is only once per question, make sure not to make careless mistakes. It's critical.
-Concept check questions(True/False questions)
need to understand concepts thoroughly more than you expected

final (50%)
- All of the course contents appears in the final exam
- divided into part 1 and part 2
  part 1 was mainly about acids and bases
  part 2 was mainly about the transition metals
- part 1 was ok but part 2 was merciless
(don't know why asked so much # of stereoisomers problems. It is unnecessary. Should have asked crystal field theory of other molecular geometries which is common to general chemistry II course)
-Some Yes/No concept questions were included.
Some of them were very deceptive.

graded quiz CH1,2 (34/40) mean: 21.5
graded quiz CH4,5 (60/60) mean: 41.1
graded quiz CH 7 (40/40) mean: 26.7

mid-term(67/80) mean: 47, high: 79,  sd: 13.3

final part 1 (47/50) mean: 32.6 high: 49
final part 2 (35/50) mean: 26.4 high: 48
                              overall final exam sd: 16.3

Overall: A
reviews.comment_workload:
three graded quizzes are out from time to time.

Practice problems in lecture notes and problem sets before the quizzes or exam and review some in-depth concepts which I mentioned in the teaching section.

reviews.author: qwerty
reviews.title: very nice prof
reviews.comment_content:
covered in midterm
Liquids and Solids: packing structure
Properties of Solutions: vapor pressure etc
Acids and Bases: lewis/ bronsted-lowry/ arrhenius definition, pauling's rule
Acid-Base Equilibria: log all the way
Solubility and Complex Ion Equilibria: ksp calculation, not unlike Acid-Base Equilibria

after midterm
Spontaneity, Entropy, and Free Energy: gibbs, thermodynamics, involves a little eqm
Electrochemistry: concentration cell, nernst equation, electrolysis, batteries
The Nucleus: A Chemistâ€™s View: dse physics elective: rate calcution
The Representative Elements: not covered but will be examined. most of it is chem 1020 stuff
Transition Metals and Coordination Chemistry: ligands, crystal field model and color of transition ions

The second part is easier to understand cuz it is just mostly calculation but they made the exam questions tricky.

1st half is not as exciting compared to the second half, but still interesting
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Lin is a very good instructor. His analogies and expressions are helpful in visualizing the concepts. Will happily answer any query you has. even though it is a 9am class, he is usually very lively and keeps ppl from falling asleep. the ppt he prepares can be a bit hard to understand. the sentences appear out of context sometimes . but still, very lively instructor who explains the concepts very clearly

TA answers emails very quickly. strict marking though. hard to argue marks back T-T

if u score 1.5 sd above mean in both, A range

nothing special

PS, he takes attendance at 9.40. if he draws ur name and u dont show up, minus 1 mark. -5 marks maximum

2 assignments
1 midterm
1 final exam

nothing too heavy

reviews.author: yyyyyy~
reviews.title: not difficult content yet bad teaching ....
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 10: Properties of Solutions
Chapter 11: Chemical Kinetics
Chapter 12: Chemical Equilibrium
Chapter 13: Acids and Bases  
Chapter 14: Acid-Base Equilibria
Chapter 15: Solubility and Complex Ion Equilibria  
Chapter 16: Spontaneity, Entropy, and Free Energy  
Chapter 17: Electrochemistry  
Chapter 18: The Nucleus: A Chemistâ€™s View  
Chapter 19: The Representative Elements  
Chapter 20: Transition Metals and Coordination Chemistry  

Compared to chem 1020 which I took in the last semester, 1030 has relatively much more maths involved. Yet, don't worry. Frankly, 1030 content is easier than 1020. One obvious thing is that the orbital thing is present in both courses. But 1030 includes less orbital stuff than 1020
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is the greatest issue in this course

1. As mentioned in previous reviews, professor Lin's English was very hard to understand. Every student in the online lecture was like a translator, translating his "Lin's English". Trust me, his English was even worse than professor Jia (another professor notorious for his English) in 1020.

2. As mentioned in previous reviews, professor Lin assumed all of us knew everything. However, it was a year 1 course and we didn't have much profound knowledge of chemistry. For example, he always assumed us know much about the organic chemistry

3. His teaching was confusing. An obvious example is that not the first time he said "Sorry I confused myself". Making mistakes in the lesson was also not the first time. Many mistakes in teaching are reminded by the students as well (Thanks students for asking questions after class in chem 1030). I skipped lessons and did self-study most of the time via YouTube (Organic Chemistry Tutor) and the website (Khan Academy)

4. To now, I really have no idea about the attendance score in 1030. After the final, he included the attendance score, but this really didn't reflect the real attendance of students. Some hardworking students who attended every lecture didn't get a full mark in attendance. Thanks to the students who keep on sending emails about attendance, the attendance part is cancelled. But, if you need to include attendance score, you should have talked about that at the beginning  

Maybe there're some good things ....

1. There're revision exercises in every lesson (all multiple choices). It is advised to capture all the MCs in the lesson as they may appear in the exam. However. most of the questions are quite unreasonable and overwhelmed with a lot of mistakes. If you come across those wrongly-set questions, dun worry, they'll not appear in the exam
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term 50% (ch.10-15)
Final 50% (ch.16-20)

1. MC
2. T/F & Short Question

reviews.author: TO Junheng
reviews.title: Nice Professor
reviews.comment_content:
This course following CHEM1020 provides students with a general view of chemistry. For Gaokao students, this course is not very difficult and you can  expect to learn something new in it.

Chapter 10: Properties of Solutions
Chapter 11: Chemical Kinetics
Chapter 12: Chemical Equilibrium
Chapter 13: Acids and Bases
Chapter 14: Acid-Base Equilibrium
Chapter 15: Solubility and Complex Ion Equilibria
Midterm Examination
Chapter 16: Spontaneity, Entropy, and Free Energy
Chapter 17: Electrochemistry
Chapter 18: The Nucleus A Chemist's View
Chapter 19: The Representative Elements (skipped)
Chapter 20: Transition Metals and Coordination Chemistry
Final Examination
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is good. Concepts are explained clearly and examples are enlightening.

Lecture notes are of good quality. If you miss a lecture, you can read the lecture note and learn by yourself without any difficulty.

Professor Lin is nice. He answers his students patiently after lectures. Also he replies email promptly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 50%     Mean: 61.7
Final 50%     Mean: 64.7
(There were two homework sets. But owing to pedagogical reasons, professor cancelled assessment on homework.)
(The assessment on attendance was also cancelled. However, this does not mean professor tolerates absence.)

The online exam is open-book. You are allowed to use both print-out materials and online materials. Even Google is allowed.

The exam paper consists of 50% multiple choice, 30% short questions, and 20% long questions. Generally speaking, multiple choice is the trickiest part since it focuses on basic concepts. It is also hard to get a high score in short question part.

The professor is very lenient in grading. My overall is only 89.5 but I got an A+! I love you professor!!!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite small. Two lectures a week and no homework :) As for the midterm and final, I prepared for each of them only for one week respectively.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Chan taught the lecture in an amazing way. Apart from talking about the notes and examples, he gave some of the experiments related to the topic that he was teaching about.

Since Prof. Chan had taken part of the incident with the girlfriend during chapter 4, Prof. Lin taught the remaining part of the course, and add a new topic on radioactive chemistry. In his lecture, although the tone was not accepted by the students, he could finish all the topics that he would cover in the final exam.

Prof. Lin would gave a toilet break during the lecture to maintain a good atmosphere of learning with heavy pressure.If there was a plenty of time, he would provide in-class exercises to familar with his style of examination.

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: Normal Grading schemes
reviews.comment_content:
This semester's CHEM1030 was taught by Prof.Chan(Dr. Fire). I guess you could have known him from TV shows or other Chem Related experiments.
There are 7 chapters to be covered this semester, they are listed as follows:

Chapter 1: Chemical Thermodynamics(Entropy)
Chapter 2: Chemical Equilibrium
Chapter 3: Solubility and Solution Properties
Chapter 4: Acids and Bases
Chapter 5: Chemical Kinetics
Chapter 6: The Main Group Elements
Chapter 7: Transition Metals

Of these 7 chapters, I would have to say that chapter 6 is one of the hardest chapters that I had ever encountered after taking CHEM1020 and CHEM1030.

Chapter 6, like other students who wrote the review of this course, found it extraordinarily hard and arduous. Chapter 6 introduces the main group elements which span from groups 1,2,13....so on and so forth. There were lots of details to be remembered and memorized. (Like what is the cubic cell of Si, Grignard reagents and Curly arrow of how NaBH4 reduces an aldehyde  )
Worse still, Dr, Chan didn't cover Chapter 6 last year so there was no past paper for Reference and revision.

As for Chapter 7, there were 2 main gists in this chapter. One is Isomerism and the other is crystal field theory. Isomerism accounted for lots of points in last year's final exam. But for this year, the MO diagram of the 3d orbital splitting into eg* and t2g accounted for higher proportions in the final exam. What's strange was that we kept practicing drawing the 3d orbital of transition metals in the lectures. But what appears in the exam were MO diagrams with 4s,4p, and 3d orbital.

These 2 chapters caused me lots of points lost in the final exam.

Last year's past paper of final exam was provided by Prof Chan for our revision
reviews.comment_teaching: Good. Interactive teaching. Sometimes he demonstrated live experiments in his class and handed out some main group elements and transitioned metals samples for us to see during the lecture. Also, he played his own video for explaining the universal indicators and the reactivity of main group elements.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is normal and is adhered to the UST grading scheme.

There are 3 assessment components.

4 Quizzes  (20%)
1 Midterm (30%)
1 Final (50%)

Scores:

Quiz1(Ch1-2): 30/40  (Mean:24.4/40 SD:Unknown High:40/40 Low 0/40)
Quiz2(Ch3-4): 47/55 (Mean: 37.8/55 SD:Unknown High:55/55 Low:0/55)
Quiz3(Ch5-6): 53/60 (Mean:45.9/60 SD:Unknown High:60/60 Low:0/60)
Quiz4(Ch7): 38/40 (Mean 25.2/40 SD:Unknown High 40/40 Low 0/40)

Midterm: 88/100 +1.775SD
(Mean 59.6/100 SD:16.0 High:93 Low:0)

Final: 83/100+3(Bonus) +1.44SD
(Mean:53.4 SD:20.5 High:102 Low:0)

Overall Course scores: 85.1

Letter Grade: A

As for the final exam, Prof.Chan gave us hints one day before the exam. The hints included the topics of the case study that we are going to encounter in the finals. (e.g. Boron, Nickel, Mg)
The last trick to score the bonus marks is to draw the structure of EDTA ligated to Mg2+ completely correct to earn the extra 3 points in the final. But i didn't  revise that
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderate.
I was shocked by the fact that there were 4 quizzes in total instead of 3 quizzes as he mentioned in his first lecture. This may be due to the fact that he wants to catch up with the schedule by having 2 make-up lectures after the typhoon. These 2 make-up lectures may give prof. Chan enough time to teach Ch6 which was disastrous for me and many students

reviews.author: wkwkwkkwkw
reviews.title: Great professor! Take the course if he's teaching it.
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Chemical Thermodynamics
Chapter 2: Chemical Equilibrium
Chapter 3: Solubility and Solution Properties
Chapter 4: Acids and Bases
Chapter 5: Chemical Kinetics
Chapter 6: The Main Group Elements
Chapter 7: Transition Metals
Chapter 8: Redox and Electrochemistry (The professor did not have enough time to cover this chapter)

Overall, I think the content of this course is pretty good. Most of the topics have already been covered in A Levels (the high school curriculum I took), but obviously it dives deeper into the topics.

Chapters 1 to 5 involve lots of calculations. Be sure to frequently do the practice sets that Dr. Chan provided and the textbook questions. Practice makes perfect, I did practice sets for each chapter every day 2 weeks before the finals. It definitely paid off.

Chapters 6 and 7 involve lots of memorisation and understanding. No calculation involved. Be sure to review the concepts taught so that you will not procrastinate before the finals.

The only complaint I have about the content of this course would be Chapter 6. Chapter 6 is just pure torture. We basically have to learn about the properties, reactions and structures of elements from Group 1 to 18. LOTS and LOTS of memorising involved. I personally think it might have been better for Dr. Chan to cover Chapter 8 instead of Chapter 6, but that's just my take on this.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Chan is an amazing professor. He speaks in a very clear manner and tone, he always gives time to his students so that they could jot down notes before he proceeds to the next slides.

He also gives very detailed lecture notes that proved to be very useful in the exams and also gives end of chapter exercises that are very similar to the questions he gives on the quizzes, midterm and finals.

He is also a very nice guy who's passionate in the subject he's teaching and always very patient when asked a question.

One thing to note is that he specialises in organic chemistry. Because of this, he often includes organic reaction mechanisms and examples. Don't think that you can skip studying these mechanisms because he might include them in the exams.

Midterm (Chapter 1-4):
My Grade: 78/100, +1.1 SD (Mean: 59.6/100. SD: 16)

The midterm questions were not that hard but they're nothing to scoff at either. I made careless calculation mistakes that cost me a lot of marks. (You can't go back to previous question after you move on to the next question). The midterm was also open book.

Finals (Chapter 1-7):
- My part 1 score: 30/30
- My part 2 score: 30/30
- My part 3 score: 35.5/40
- My finals score: 95.5/100, +2.01 SD (Mean: 54.2/100. SD: 20.5)

The final was a closed book exam. It was difficult, especially considering the fact that the time duration was honestly not enough (I finished 3 minutes before time's up). Part 1 and 2 was very doable. Part 3, on the other hand, was crazy. Split into three parts: Part 1 (MCQ), Part 2 (Case Study 1) and Part 3 (Case study 2 and 3).

The grading for this course is quite good. My friend who got around 81-83 was able to get an A.

The cutoff for A+ is probably around 86-88 (?). Getting an 85 would still give you an A according to another ust.space reviewer.

My total grade for the course: 89.
Letter Grade: A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light. He does not give homework but frequent study and exercise is vital.

The content is continued from CHEM1020. But you can still understand CHEM1030 even if you have not studied CHEM1020.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Lin has some accent but the explanation is very clear and understandable. He is always enthusiastic to answer any questions.
In the second half of the semester, I had some difficulties after the new lecturer came to teach the class, probably due to my personal problems. On the one hand, I was not quite used to the new lecturer's classroom habits, and on the other hand, I missed a few classes due to illness. As a result, I was not able to understand the content of Chapter 20 clearly at first. But later, during the final review, I read the slides and reviewed the return visits, and asked the professor and TA for advice, and I quickly understood the content.
The professors, assistants and TAs were all very enthusiastic. They speak Cantonese, English, and Mandarin, so it was very easy to communicate with them.

But I still think there is room for improvement. This is a course with a very large number of students. However, a lot of local students don't listen to the class at all and like to talk to each other, which affects the class experience. So, I think we can change the rules so that instead of uploading the recordings a week later, we can upload the recordings at the same time, so that all the students who don't listen to the class don't come to the class. Otherwise, we have to waste a lot of time on maintaining order in every class. Also, the background sound of each session's recording is very noisy. Because there are a bunch of locals who don't listen to the class at all.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think grading is much better than the math and physics courses.
Mid-term exam -- 45%
Final exam -- 45%
Assignments 1 & 2 -- 5% Ã— 2

Assignment1: 28/28 (mean: 24.7)
Assignment2: 40/40 (mean: 37.9)
Letter grading: A+

I think it's a very good course
reviews.comment_workload: There is hardly any workload. There are only two assignments. assignments are very simple and can be submitted an unlimited number of times. So you can get a perfect score as many times as you want. So the final distinction is still based on the midterm and final exam.

reviews.comment_teaching:
This semester all classes are online. Professor take attendance every lecture and said that those who skipped too many lectures will get deduction in the 5%attendance. However, as he later forgot to write that in an announcement, he abandoned the attendance in the end.
      Some of my classmates and some previous reviews think his teaching is very engaging and explain things vividly, but I think his teaching is not that good and I prefer reading the textbook by myself to learn more efficiently and learn in a more organized way. I think he just keep saying things like "this guy", "that guy", "let's say"...And his English isn't very good. He didn't seem very well-prepared as he sometimes don't know whether a question on the slides have answers in the next page or not. And he made some mistakes when explaining things. (but professors all make mistakes sometimes, and he send emails to clarify his mistakes, so it's...ok, maybe)
     There are three good things about his teaching. One is that he always give some review questions at the beginning of the lecture, and that helps to consolidate your knowledge. I screencapped all of them and they are useful for revision. Another good thing is that he gives a short break in the lecture. Thirdly, he is wililng to answer questions after lectures. (Altough some questions occur simply because he explained things wrongly in class)
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very generous. In this semester, overall 88 gives you an A+ and the exam is really not difficult as long as you studied in the semester and did revision. In this semester, midterm: mean61.8, sd16.6, final exam: mean64.4, sd16.84. But maybe it is not a good reference since both midterm and final exams are held online this semester. There are 20 multiple choice questions, several gap-fillings and 2 long questions.
reviews.comment_workload: There is one problem set for each chapter, but they are only for your practice and you don't need to hand in them. Every week there is one tutorial (not written in the timetable) explaining one problem set in detail. Originally there should be two graded assignments, but they are changed into exercise to release some stress on students under bad covid situation this semester. I also read the textbook besides doing the problem sets, but I consider the overall workload to be low. (compared to other science courses, I think)

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Lin provides a lot of help, if you email him, he answers pretty quickly. He gives out a lot of practice problems, although I think they are too easy and not that helpful for preparing you for the exams (they are like baits tbh). At the start of every lesson, he does polling on practice MCQ problems which are hard, if you attend all of it, I suggest that you attempt them all, and you might be able to identify his way of asking questions so even during MT or Finals you can sort of guess the answer. Overall, pretty good prof, pretty helpful and kind (except for exams), and he does stay behind after every lecture to answer as many questions.

Other than that, for some reason content before the MT, he was god awful at explaining things, like it was more confusing than helping. so I just self studied everything from that point onwards. However, sometimes he gives good advice and hints on how to do certain questions. Then after MT, the content for finals, he somehow explains things super clearly and it wasnt confusing.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof LIN is a passionate lecturer, and each class begins with some polling questions to help you understand and review the previous chapter. And he is very patient to answer every question.
I don't recommend skipping classes, because there may be things mentioned in class that are not in the textbook, although they won't appear on the exam paper.
reviews.comment_grading: It is easier to get good grades as long as you have learned these things. The average score on the exam was below 60%, and if you had any doubts about your score about your examï¼Œ you could ask in the paper checking session and the professor/TA may add some points for you if your doubts are reasonable.
reviews.comment_workload: As long as you listen carefully, you will not have any workload. There are two homework assignments before the mid-term and the final, which will help you review along the way, so it's not too stressful. But if you want to achieve high grades, you need to work harder than others.

reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Chemical Thermodynamics
Chapter 2: Chemical Equilibrium
Chapter 3: Solubility and Solution Properties
Chapter 4: Acids and Bases
Chapter 5: Chemical Kinetics
Chapter 7: Transition Metals

We didn't have time to learn Chapter 6: The main group elements and Chapter 8: Redox and Electrochemistry.

The hardest chapter out of them all is chapter 3 as students often make careless mistakes in their calculation.

For those who have taken A level, the newest chapter is chapter 7 as we learn strong field, weak field ligands, and how do we obtain the orbital splitting due to ligand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Chan explains the concepts thoroughly and always answers the students' questions. What I like about his teaching the most is that he give you lecture notes (Not presentation, but literally lecture note in word form).

As you can see from the content part, because he always explained everything in detail and gave some practice problems during the class, he did not have time to teach chapters 6 and 8. This reduces the number of chapters you need to learn in the final exam :D.

If you saw Prof Chan teaching this course again, take it!

Also, those that enjoy Organic Chemistry will love his teaching as Prof Chan will add some organic related stuff into his teaching. (They are not tested in the exam, but at least it will quench your boredom during the class).

reviews.comment_teaching: Professors are nice and willing to answer your questions. So efficient that they answer your questions right away after lectures. One thing to praise is the IA (Elaine Wong), she replied to our emails quickly and answer our enquiries clearly. Better ask Elaine before you ask professors, waste less time :))))
reviews.comment_grading:
assignments 20% (10%/assigment) :
homework 1 95/100 (mean: 69.4)
homework 2 94/100 (mean: 67.3)

midterm 40%: 53.67/100 (mean: 53.5 SD:16.61)
final 40%: 79.8/100 (mean: 70.38 SD:13.61)
exam format: T/F , MC, matching
final grade: B+ (71.8/100)
letter grade cut-off (given by IA)
>90  A+     >80  A         >75    A-
>70 B+      >65  B          >61   B-
>55 C+      >45  C          >42   C-
>35 D
reviews.comment_workload:
very light, with only two assignments.
better revise all the homework released after each lecture and finish the past paper given by the professor, the final exam duplicated some questions from the past paper.

reviews.author: Quaesitor
reviews.title: Easy course with little effort
reviews.comment_content: This is the second Chemistry course for the first year students. The content is about enthalpy, entropy and essentially everything in chapter 11-20.
reviews.comment_teaching: Despite much humor, LIN do have very strong accent which is unbearable at first, but you will found it acceptable after you had a few lecture with him. LIN have a very strong sense of humor and there are many interaction between students and LIN. LIN do present his idea very well but I found that I donâ€™t have much interest in Chemistry so I decided to just play with my mobile phone instead. Ian donâ€™t have any kind of accent problem but his sense of humor is a bit less than LIN. Ian likes to include many materials which is out of syllabus and difficult to understand as an freshmen just entered university (IRE students ignore this), by and large the lecture they held was quite interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was based on cumulative curve, however you may found very little effort you need to pay to get a good grade. I got 69.5/100 in first assignment, 36.53/50 for assignment 2, 70.5/100 in midterm and 85 in final (not sure about total marks are there in final).
reviews.comment_workload: As I said before I essentially didnâ€™t do much, all I did is just hand in homework, revise a day or two before the exams and literally didnâ€™t pay much attention in class as they are all secondary school play. If you took CHEM in HKDSE you will find that all the topics has been gone through in Sec 4-6 with some in-depth discussion of topics. It is essentially A-level syllabus and nothing difficult.

reviews.author: Kate Xu
reviews.title: Good teaching
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm:
1. properties of solutions
2. chemical kinetics
3. chemical equilibriums
4. acids and bases
5. acid-base equilibria
6. solubility and complex ion equilibria

Final:
1. spontaneity, entropy and free energy
2. electrochemistry
3. the nucleus: a chemist's view
4. the representative elements
5. transition metals and coordination chemistry

The lecture notes were very specific and well prepared but you better got a textbook.
reviews.comment_teaching: Both instructors teaches well and offers helpful explanations to any questions. Their voices were clear to hear and easy to understand. IPRS was used to take attendance by two instructors.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty good.
reviews.comment_workload: A lot to learn. There were two assignments each before midterm and final.

reviews.author: L'amour, La vie
reviews.comment_content: Content level is easy relative to that of Chem 1010, as things are macroscopic and mainly about calculations, unlike what happened in Chem 1010 in which we have to understand messy concepts like Quantum Mechanical Models. Topics which are difficult in my opinion are solubility, equilibrium and thermal dynamics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lin and Williams are two different instructors.
For Lin, he tends to teach things in a deeper level and so both his powerpoints and teaching are detailed. He is also a fun guy and sometimes makes the lesson enjoyable by making jokes.
For Williams, he tends to make things simple and neat and so both his powerpoints and test paper are easy.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two assignments, 1 mid 1 final and some attendance marks.
Didn't do the first assignment and watched lecture videos at home instead of attending the lecture.
Got a C at the end.(My fault, not the course's fault)
I think the final is too easy such that it is difficult to distinguish good from bad.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light. Just two online assignments composed of around 15 questions each. Questions are based on the examples in the powerpoints so you will find no difficulties in completing them. You should get 90 to 100 per cent. Final and mids are also easy, on the condition that you have mastered the calculations in the powerpoints.

reviews.author: è‚¯å°¼å«
reviews.comment_content:
Harder than CHEM 1020, but still some of those are included in high school.

Midterm
- Properties of Solutions
- Acids and Bases
- Acid-Base Equilibria
- Solubility and Complex Ion Equilibria

Final
- Spontaneity, Entropy, and Free Energy
- Electrochemistry
- The Nucleus: A Chemistâ€™s View

reviews.comment_teaching: Slides of Prof. Lin are neat and clear, but Prof. Williams's are a bit messy and there are several versions of the same chapter, which is very annoying. (You will not know which one is the right one he is using.)
reviews.comment_grading:
Both of them take attendance, a meaningless and frustrating strategy to keep the lecture theater full of people.

5% attendance each professor, 45% of midterm and final respectively.
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate, but reading the slides of prof. Williams is tiring (psychologically).

reviews.author: WilliamLeung
reviews.title: GEN. CHEMISTRY II
reviews.comment_content:
Liquids and Solids
Properties of Solutions
Acids and Bases
Acid-Base Equilibria
Solubility and Complex Ion Equilibria


Spontaneity, Entropy, and Free Energy

reviews.comment_teaching:
For Prof. LIN:
He uses examples to explain difficult concepts and shows worked-out problems in the lectures.
He takes attendance by randomly select 15 students every lecture.

For Prof. IAN:
-He somehow reads aloud the powerpoints he uploaded 2 days before the lectures.
-Some lecture ppt extends 100 pages.
-He doesn't have good time management, he rushed the last topics(Transition Metals).
-Be prepared (read the ppts yourself before the lessons, because of the iPRS question he posted is already in those ppts)
-He takes attendance by counting how many iPRS you answered correctly.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 assignments due before mid-term and final

mid-term is difficult for me (prof. LIN)
you need a lot of practice

final is easier because Prof. Ian is behind the planned timetable, so he deleted some parts for the final
and his research interest is silicon(he mentioned many things about silicon, and put 2-3 questions in the final exam paper)
reviews.comment_workload:
the reading assignment (textbook) is up to you
but it's recommended

reviews.author: ustsadsadsad
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are quite concrete and quantitative compared with CHEM1020, far easier to understand.
Contents taught after mid-term may be harder to understand (still easier than chem1020), but can be understood if spend some time read textbooks
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecturer who taught the contents in mid-term can explain and elaborate concepts effectively accompanied with appropriate amount of examples. Always talk to students to check their progress during breaks. Nice and amiable. Willing to help students.

I personally don't like the teaching style of Williams because his ppts are too lengthy and he included too many extra things in class so it makes the lesson quite hard to follow if you are not focused enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is reasonable.
Determined by assignments (2), mid-term, final, attendance
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite reasonable workload.
If wanna attain a high grade, need to study all materials and finish all homework (no need to submit) and revision materials provided (no need to submit).
If you are not good at calculations, workload may be even heavier because the course require quite a lot of calculations.

Head of Chemistry Department's teaching must be very good! haha!!!

Lecture videos are provided
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 45%
Finals 47%
2 assignments in total (before and after midterm) 8%
Take attendance but it is randomly drawn.

if you get almost full mark in two assignments and above 0.5 sd in both exam, I pretty sure u can get B/B+ in final grade.
reviews.comment_workload: light workload. 2 assignments, 1 midterm and 1 final.

reviews.author: rainie
reviews.comment_content: difficult, hard to understand. with lesson video, you can review after lessons. big difference from the content you have learnt in your secondary school.
reviews.comment_teaching: clear powerpoint is provided. but we have to search some principles and reasons online as some content only include statement or equation. so its not easy to understand
reviews.comment_grading: c-
reviews.comment_workload: light workload. 2 assignments, 1midterm and 1 final in 1 semester.quite light workload but you have to take attendance during the classes.  professor will pick 10 students to take attendance in each lesson.1 mark will be deducted from final mark if you are absent.

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.title: A-Level Chemistry
reviews.comment_content:
A-Level Chemistry untaught in DSE

- Molarity & Molality
- Raoult's Law, Partial Pressures
- von't Hoff Factor
- Freezing Point Depression
- Boiling Point Elevation
- Ideal Gas Law & its Deviations
â˜… Acid-Base Equilibria (pKa, pKb etc.)

Mid-Term Exam (late March before Easter)

- Solubility Product (Ksp)
- 2nd Law of Thermodynamics
â˜…â˜…â˜… Entropy (Î”S), Gibb's Free Energy (Î”G = Î”H - TÎ”S)
- Electrochemistry (Nernst's Equation)
- Transition Metal-Ligand Compounds (d-orbital splitting, strong/weak field ligands)

Final Exam (late May)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Lin is not excellent at lecturing, but he is a very committed teacher and scientist. He is very amiable and responsive to us in case of doubt.

You may meet him again if you take CHEM 2210 in the following semester.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term: 44%
Final: 48%
Assignments: 4% x 2 = 8%
Mark Deduction for Absence

He randomly chose a number of students on his computer and asked them to record their attendance with him every recess, like what he did when teaching CHEM 2210.

My Mid-Term Exam: 49.5/100 (mean: 47/100)
My Final Exam: 58/100 (mean: 52.3/100)
Eventual Grade: B

Despite having been a bit lower than what I had expected, it could still be seen as fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
The two fairly hard assignments.

Also a number of ungraded exercises for self-practice, if you aim high.

Attendance (If not attended, marks will be deducted)
reviews.comment_workload:
Two assignment only.
The hardest thing is to wake up early to attend the 9am lecture.

reviews.author: Hyperion
reviews.comment_content: I'd like to say that the contents are really easy because all of them are covered in the general chemistry and the word "general" means every one can understand it if he spends some efforts on it. So do not worry about it. Just attend every lecture and do you best.
reviews.comment_teaching: As the head of the Department of Chemistry, I have to say Lin is a good teacher. His lectures are easy to follow and understand. Because of the same reasons, if you understand what he is teaching, you may easily fall asleep.
reviews.comment_grading: It's easy to get an A range as long as you understand all the lectures. Because there are almost 400 students in this class and the grading is strictly based on the grading curve. And most of them do not concentrate on the lectures or even skip it. This means there are many students falling behind you if you attend every lecture and understand it.
reviews.comment_workload: There are only two assignments that should be submitted during the lecture. You just need to review what you learned before the exams. Alright, another thing annoy is that you should attend every lecture because there is a lucky draw. The lucky person that does not show up will be deducted one point from his final grade.

reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was clear and he can explain the concept well, he was willing to answer students question clearly after the end of lectures, which can clarify some of the difficult concepts encountered in some topics. There are random attendance during the lectures, 5 students will be randomly selected and 1% will be deducted if you are absent.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term: 44%
Final: 48%
Assignments x 2: 8%
I got full marks on both assignments and 1SD above mean in both midterm and final exam, finally got A- Grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was light, only two assignments need to be handed before the mid-term and final exam.

reviews.comment_content: Topics are still related with high school chemistry, not that too hard as long as you review his lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching was clear enough, you can always approach him to ask questions and he is willing to answer you during the break time in class. He also let the class ended earlier sometimes. However, he also took random attendance in every class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is quite lenient.
Mid term - 44% ; Final - 48% ; Assignments - 8%
I got slightly above mean for the mid term, 0.5 SD above mean for the final exam and almost full point for both assignments, still got B+ for my final grade.
reviews.comment_workload: There are only 2 assignments which worth 4% each. He also gives long time to do the assignments. So, there are not many workloads to do.

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.comment_content:
Continuation of CHEM 1010/1020 (General Chemistry IA/IB). Topics include:
Stoichiometry
Solutions
Acids and Bases
Complex Ions
Spontaneity and Entropy
Electrochemistry
Nuclear Chemistry
Representative Elements
Coordination Chemistry

Content is not too hard. This is a prerequisite for higher chemistry courses such as Organic or Inorganic Chemistry.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was clear and he explained the concepts well. But the lectures can be quite boring and monotonous at times. A lot of people skip them as the lecture slides and video recordings of the lectures are uploaded online, and the lectures are at 9:00 am.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term: 44%
Final: 48%
Assignments (2): 4+4 = 8%
The assignments have a very high mean as you have many days/weeks to complete them. Exams have quite low means (around 50%).
I got 0.5 SD above mean in midterm, 1 SD above mean in final, slightly above mean in assignments = A- grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not a lot of workload. 2 assignments, both are quite straightforward and you get many days to complete them. Most people score quite high on them. The exams are not very hard, only need to read through the lecture slides and solve the past paper uploaded on Canvas.
There is random attendance taken at lectures, where they select any 5 student ID numbers (out of 300+) and check for attendance in the middle of each lecture. If you are absent you will get -1% in the overall grade. I did not attend any lectures but did not get any deduction for attendance.

reviews.author: iVanYip
reviews.comment_content:
Main content include:
- solution (concentration, solubility, equilibrium...)
- acid and base (nature of acid and base, pH and pK, buffer and neutralization...)
- thermochemistry (enthalpy, entropy, free energy...)
- electrochemistry (redox, cell and cell potential, electrolysis...)
- nuclear chemistry and radioactivity
- chemistry pattern
- transitional elements and coordination chemistry (bond model for transitional elements, isomerism, etc...)
reviews.comment_teaching: Lin was willing to answer student's question despite his strange English accent.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading depends on students' results in mid-term (44%), final exam(48%) and assignments (4%*2). The exam questions are quite difficult and require students linking several concepts (e.g. the relationship between free energy, equilibrium and cell potential). It is not easy to get a high mark as a result.


Attendance also contributes to one's grade. Lin will randomly check if students have attended his class. Students may have marks deducted if they do not attend the class.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light. Only two assignments need to be handed in before exams.
Although homework is given in the course, they are only supplementary materials, and student do not need to hand in them.

reviews.comment_content: Lin covers the important contents in the textbook, leaving almost nothing. However, Williams skips many main parts and focuses on several subtle parts, and he loves to cover those subtle parts in the exams, which makes reviewing impossible.

Both of the professors have difficulty controlling the order of the class.
Williams tends to digress, wasting a huge amount of time.

Both teachings are boring, making me sleepy.

Quite good.

reviews.author: lhtam
reviews.title: A self-study course for chem noobs
reviews.comment_content:
Before mid-term (Taught by Prof LIN)
Chapter 10:Properties of Solutions
Chapter 11:Chemical Kinetics*
Chapter 12:Chemical Equilibrium*
Chapter 13:Acids and Bases
Chapter 14:Acid-Base Equilibria
Chapter 15:Solubility and Complex Ion Equilibria
*New topic that haven't taught in previous years

After mid-term  (Taught by Prof WILLIAMS)
Chapter 16:Spontaneity, Entropy, and Free Energy
Chapter 17:Electrochemistry
Chapter 18:The Nucleus: A Chemistâ€™s View
Chapter 19:The Representative Elements
Chapter 20:Transition Metals and Coordination Chemistry

Prof WILLIAMS rushed over chapter 19-20 so you have to do self-studying basically. However, some contents in chapter 20 are taught in CHEM1010 / CHEM1020 already.
reviews.comment_teaching: TBH both professors are passionate in teaching, despite most of the students are not listening actually. Since I didn't study chemistry in high school so I found their teaching is useless as they assume we acquired those concepts in high school already, and everything they explained require basic chemistry knowledge in high school (especially the equilibrium part). So I basically doing self-study in the whole semester.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since there are two professors in this year, they adopt different grading methods.

For Prof LIN:
- 5% Attendance (15 students will be randomly drawn in the middle of every lecture, deduct 1% each if you didn't show up)
- 5% Assignment 1 (Around 10 pages, hard-copy is needed)
- 40% Mid-term (50% MC and 50% LQ, most questions are calculation based, equations will be provided and marks will only be given with correct STEPS and ANSWERS, quite difficult thus the mean is only around 55% and SD is 17)

For Prof WILLIAMS:
- 5% Attendance (Done by answering questions in iPRS every lesson. The more correct answer you get, the higher marks you get in attendance so the 5% attendance will be given in a linear scale in class i.e. Top 20% student will get full marks and the remaining will get 4.8% - 0%)
- 5% Assignment 2 (Canvas typed assignment, you could complete all two attempts but only the last attempt will be kept even you score higher in first attempt, however, they won't release your score after your first attempt and questions are different in both attempts)
- 40% Final Exam (20% T/F, 50% MCQ, 30% entered/numerical questions. Quantitative and qualitative knowledge are equally important. Comparatively less demanding in final exam)

Grading:
Overall scores 80-100%: A range (15.7% of students)
Overall scores 66-79%: B range (31.8% of students)
Overall scores 45-65%: C range (46.1% of students)
Overall scores 38-44%: D (4.8% of students)
Overall scores below 38%: F (1.5% of students)
reviews.comment_workload: For student who ever study chemistry in high school, you need to spend much time to understand the content (especially the equilibrium part as it's quite confusing). Go watch Organic Chemistry Tutor on YouTube and doing exercises provided in textbook are more effective than listening in lectures as you won't be able to understand the concepts anyway.

reviews.author: TH WONG
reviews.title: Nice Course
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers topics that students more or less have some basic ideas from HKDSE Chem. It is kinda like an extension of a few DSE topics which includes some A-level stuffs. Not a difficult course, but make sure you really understand the concepts taught. I think students who are interested in chemistry would be interested in this course :)

1) Topics included in the mid-term exam:
-Chapter 9:Liquids and Solids
-Chapter 10:Properties of Solutions
-Chapter 13:Acids and Bases
-Chapter 14:Acid-Base Equilibria
-Chapter 15:Solubility and Complex Ion Equilibria

DSE topics with newer concepts. The content is quite easy, I would say the calculations about the equilibria is the hardest part (harder than those in DSE).

2) Topics include in the final exam:
-Chapter 16: Spontaneity, Entropy, and Free Energy
-Chapter 17: Electrochemistry
-Chapter 18:The Nucleus: A Chemistâ€™s View
-Chapter 19:The Representative Elements
(wasn't taught and included in the final as there wasn't enough time to teach plus this topic is simple, Prof. Lin just encouraged us to read it at home)
-Chapter 20:Transition Metals and Coordination Chemistry

These chapters dig deeper into some DSE topics (except chapter 18, which is more or less included in DSE Physics), but generally they aren't very hard to understand and are interesting. As long as students understand the concepts, it would be fine to handle the final.

The attendance is taken by randomly rolling 10 students in the middle break of each lecture. Prof. Lin refers this as 'the lucky draw' :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Lin, as mentioned in many other reviews also, teaches with passion, explains things well and clear.
Also, he is very nice, just feel free to ask him questions if you don't understand or aren't clear about the concepts.

The instructional assistant KaHo is also very helpful and always answers students' questions with clear explanations.

Lecture videos will be uploaded to canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term: 45%
Final: 47%
Assignment: 4% each, 2 assignments (8% in total)
Attendance: Deduction (3% maximum)

I think the final is easier than the midterm as there are less calculations in the final.

Assignment 1: 81/100 (mean 87)
Mid-term: 86/100 (mean 50.4)
Assignment 2: 95/100 (mean 87.2)
Final: 90/100 (mean 64.4)
Attendance: 0% (mean -0.2%)
Total: 88.04%
Grade: A+

I think the grading is good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is light.
Just 2 assignments (one before midterm and one before the final).

Not much study is required, but make sure you really understand the content, and can utilize the concepts in answering questions/doing calculations/explaining phenomenons.

reviews.comment_workload:
The biggest workload is attendance, since the lesson starts at 9:00am and professor takes attendance at mid-lesson break at ~9:40am. However, I don't have hall and live in Sha Tin. You know what I mean.

When he takes attendance, he asked the TA to scroll down the Excel table of the student list and stops upon his command. The 10 lucky students that appears on the screen will be asked to come down with student ID for attendance. If he/she didn't show up, 1% will be deducted from the total mark, max. 5 times.. So, evaluate your luck before skipping lessons. Just a warning, I got picked for attendance for 4 times throughout the semester(400 students in the course), so don't be surprised if you are also that lucky...

The assignments require 4-6 hours each to finish depending on your source/understanding. This is no big deal since there are only 2 assignments in the semester.

The exams are harder than the past papers provided. Be careful. Don't mess up the + - signs and lose 5 marks like me.

reviews.author: RichardY
reviews.comment_content: This general chemistry course consists of different sorts of calculations related to properties of aqueous solution, equilibrium (acid-base, buffer, solubility), thermodynamics, electrochemistry and nuclear chemistry. The hardest part in my opinion is thermodynamics as it really takes you quite some time to digest all the concepts. However, the most crucial part in the exam is equilibrium because it is being tested most and its concepts are key to the understanding of other parts as well. A quite well-designed course in my opinion in terms of enriching students' basic knowledge of chemistry.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lin is a good teacher, he can deliver contents efficiently. He is also a very responsible and knowledgeable person in my opinion.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is rather good in my opinion. I had a slight slip in the final exam but still managed an A+. My overall score is ~ 91%. The midterm mean is ~74.x% ,final mean is ~56.x% and S.D. is 14.x.(final exam is rather hard, quite different from the standard of sample papers, assignments and midterm. It is also not well-designed at some points which cost me extra time during exam and the questions turned out to be problematic i.e. having multiple correct answers).
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is slightly heavier than CHEM1020 (the prerequisite of 1030). Since it is a rather quantitative course (in contrast to CHEM1020 which is very qualitative), it requires you spending some more time to practice the calculation in order to get an A+.

reviews.title: Easy Peasy Lemon's Squeezyy
reviews.comment_content:
More advanced secondary school things.
1. Solutions (calculate vapour pressure, osmotic pressure etc)
2. Acids and Bases (calculate pH)
3. Solubility and Complex Ion Equilibria (solubility product)

4. Spontaneity, Entropy, and Free Energy (Physical Chem.)
5. Electrochemistry (cell voltage)
6. The Nucleus: A Chemistâ€™s View (decay, fission and fusion, stability of nuclei)
7.  The Representative Elements (properties of elements, silicates)
8.  Transition Metals and Coordination Chemistry (trends of transition metals, isomerism, d-orbit mixing)

LIGHT

Assignment 1: 9 A4 pages hand-written work. Just some calculations, explanations, etc. Just ask for others help if needed/

Assignment 2: Done on Canvas. Easy. However the questions are randomly selected from a question bank, so it is harder to check ans with other ppl.

Mid-Term: Easy. There were even hints. No need to revise

Final: Easy. Not even requires steps for calculations.

reviews.author: _Donald_
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly related to Dse chemistry
stoichiometry and chemical reactions
properties of aqueous solutions,
acids and bases,
thermodynamics and equilibrium,
electrochemistry,
general aspects in the chemistry of the main-group elements
introduction to transition metal elements and coordination compounds.
If you have studied Dse chemistry, it would be quite easy for you especially for the chapters like acid and base or electrochemistry
But you need to put more focus on the last few chapters as they are not included in the Dse chemistry
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures are just quite boring especially for the lectures of Williams. He just read through the ppt without much further elaboration
reviews.comment_grading:
Poor grading
Midterm - 44% ; Final - 48% ; Assignments - 8%
I got slightly above mean for the midterm, 0.5 SD above mean for the final exam and 80% for both assignments, still got B+ for my final grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Have two assignments that need to be handed in.
MIdterm+final exam
You better start your revision a week earlier as the contents are a bit hard to understand
